body.p: A study was conducted to estimate μ, the mean commute distance that all employed U.S. adults travel to work. Suppose a random sample of 49 employed U.S. adults gives a mean commute distance of 22 miles and that from prior studies, the population standard deviation is assumed to be σ = 8.4 miles.
We are 95% confident that the mean commute distance to work of all employed U.S. adults falls between which of the following intervals?

response.feedback: Incorrect. It appears that you found the 68% confidence interval, x̄ ± 1 * σ/√n, for the mean instead of the 95% confidence interval.
Incorrect. It appears that you forgot to calculate the standard error of the mean (σ/√n) before computing the interval.
Correct. The 95% confidence interval for the mean, μ, is x̄ ± 2 * σ/√n = 22 ± 2 * 8.4/√49 = 22 ± 2(1.2) = 22 ± 2.4 = 19.6 to 24.4.
Incorrect. It appears you forgot to multiply the 95% critical value by the standard deviation (σ/√n).
